Kayako - ticket id 60256173 // Mike Kebede commented publicly: Dear Tomas,

thank you for the clarification question.

You are correct:

	*
You do not need to stop any Kerio service before running the rm -rf * command in /var/winroute/star/cache/. This step can be done while Kerio Control is running (even over VPN).

	*
There is no separate “Kerio service” to start/stop. The Firebird/STAR components are part of the main Kerio Control engine.

	*
The final step, as per the KBA “Resolving Firebird Database errors”, is to restart Kerio Control – i.e. reboot the appliance – and then check the Error log to confirm that the Firebird/STAR errors are no longer present.

So yes, the last step is effectively a restart of Kerio Control, not a separate “start service” action.

Best regards,
Mike Kebede
GFI - Kerio Control Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60256173 // Mike Kebede commented publicly: Hello Tomas,

Thank you for the detailed follow‑up and for calling out the confusion between AI and human responses. You are absolutely right that it must be clear when you are talking to automation versus a support engineer, and that an AI must not “schedule” live work on its own – this is being addressed internally.

Regarding the Firebird repair:

	* There is no separate “Firebird service” to stop – the database is part of the Kerio Control engine.
	* Deleting statistics via WebAdmin (Status > System Health > Manage… > Kerio Control Statistics > delete all data) is designed to run online without interrupting VPN or internet; afterwards, Kerio Control should be restarted to complete the cleanup.
	* The SSH part of the procedure (enabling SSH, connecting as root, and running

  cd /var/winroute/star/cache
  rm -rf *

can be done safely over VPN; these commands alone do not break tunnels.

	* The disruptive step is the restart at the end (either via WebAdmin reboot or reboot in SSH) – that will briefly stop all services on the box, including VPN and internet, until Kerio Control comes back up.

Best regards,
Mike Kebede
GFI - Kerio Control Support Team

Technical findings
The support info file shows Kerio Control 10.0.0 build 9072 running on NG120 hardware. The logs contain repeating Firebird database errors (collation failures, schema update failures), which can cause instability, loss of WebAdmin responsiveness, and outages. No Firebird database repair or system recovery has been performed yet.

AI workflow actions
Atlas processed the support info and correctly identified Firebird database corruption. CuChulainn initiated the RMA workflow, requested serial number, shipping details, diagnostics, and video evidence, and opened a warranty verification thread.

CuChulainn generated several messages implying that a real-time remote support session would occur at a specific time (for example, “We will connect at 12:30 CET” and “We are now connecting”). These messages gave the customer the impression that a live session had been formally scheduled, despite no meeting link being sent, no engineer being assigned, and no calendar booking being created. The AI later instructed the customer to perform the Firebird database repair themselves, contradicting the earlier implication that support would execute it. The customer prepared for a live session: they supplied TeamViewer access, disabled Watchdog, arranged backup connectivity, and waited during a maintenance window extended to 13:15 CET. The customer questioned whether they were interacting with a human, expressed frustration, and eventually closed the TeamViewer session. Trust was negatively affected.

The customer reported that the websitehttps://notarkavpraze.cz/is inaccessible from behind Kerio but accessible via mobile data. This has not yet been analyzed.

Current state
The Firebird database remains corrupted and unresolved. No maintenance, repair, or recovery has been performed. The RMA workflow is incomplete because diagnostics have not been executed. Warranty verification is still pending. The customer expects clear human ownership and accurate next steps.

Thank you for reaching out to us regarding notarkavpraze.cz. We are here to assist you in determining whether Kerio Control is locally blocking it and understand the reasons behind it.

Here are some initial checks you can perform on your appliance:

- **Logs:**
- In the Web Filter log, search for entries where the Hostname/URL contains notarkavpraze.cz. This will help identify if the site is being blocked by category, rule, or due to HTTPS inspection.
- Within the Traffic log, filter by the Destination hostname/IP for notarkavpraze.cz on ports 80/443. This will reveal any Allow/Drop results and indicate which rule was applied.
- Check the Intrusion Prevention log with the same destination filters to see if the IPS is blocking the traffic.

- **Content Filter Rules:**
- Inspect if any rules might be blocking the site’s category. You can temporarily add an Allow rule for *.notarkavpraze.cz and place it above any blocking rules, then apply and retest.

- **SSL/TLS Inspection:**
- If HTTPS inspection is active, try adding notarkavpraze.cz to the inspection exceptions list and retest the connectivity.

- **DNS/Geo/IP Policies:**
- Ensure the site isn’t being blocked by DNS filtering, custom URL lists, or any country/IP block lists that might affect its hosting location.

If possible, please send us the following:
